Moses did as the Lord had commanded and sent these twelve tribal leaders: Shammua, son of Zaccur, from the tribe of Reuben; Shaphat, son of Hori, from the tribe of Simeon; Caleb, son of Jephunneh, from the tribe of Judah; Igal, son of Joseph, from the tribe of Issachar; Hoshea, son of Nun, from the half-tribe of Ephraim; Palti, son of Raphu, from the tribe of Benjamin; Gaddiel, son of Sodi, from the tribe of Zebulun; Gaddi, son of Susi, from the tribe of Joseph (actually, the half-tribe of Manasseh); Ammiel, son of Gemalli, from the tribe of Dan; Sethur, son of Michael, from the tribe of Asher; Nahbi, son of Vophsi, from the tribe of Naphtali; Geuel, son of Machi, from the tribe of Gad.

16.verse: It was at this time that Moses changed Hoshea’s name to Joshua.

17.verse: Moses sent them out with these instructions: “Go northward into the hill country of the Negeb,

18.verse: and see what the land is like; see also what the people are like who live there, whether they are strong or weak, many or few;

19.verse: and whether the land is fertile or not; and what cities there are, and whether they are villages or are fortified;

20.verse: whether the land is rich or poor, and whether there are many trees. Don’t be afraid, and bring back some samples of the crops you see.” (The first of the grapes were being harvested at that time.)

21.verse: So they spied out the land all the way from the wilderness of Zin to Rehob near Hamath.

22.verse: Going northward, they passed first through the Negeb and arrived at Hebron. There they saw the Ahimanites, Sheshites, and Talmites, all families descended from Anak. (By the way, Hebron was very ancient, having been founded seven years before Tanis in Egypt.)

23.verse: Then they came to what is now known as the valley of Eshcol where they cut down a single cluster of grapes so large that it took two of them to carry it on a pole between them! They also took some samples of the pomegranates and figs.

24.verse: The Israelis named the valley “Eshcol” at that time (meaning “Cluster”) because of the cluster of grapes they found!

25.verse: After forty days of exploration they returned from their tour.

26.verse: They made their report to Moses, Aaron, and all the people of Israel in the wilderness of Paran at Kadesh, and they showed the fruit they had brought with them.

27.verse: This was their report: “We arrived in the land you sent us to see, and it is indeed a magnificent country—a land ‘flowing with milk and honey.’ Here is some fruit we have brought as proof.

28.verse: But the people living there are powerful, and their cities are fortified and very large; and what’s more, we saw Anakim giants there!

29.verse: The Amalekites live in the south, while in the hill country there are the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites; down along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea and in the Jordan River Valley are the Canaanites.”

30.verse: But Caleb reassured the people as they stood before Moses. “Let us go up at once and possess it,” he said, “for we are well able to conquer it!”

31.verse: “Not against people as strong as they are!” the other spies said. “They would crush us!”

32.verse: So the majority report of the spies was negative: “The land is full of warriors, the people are powerfully built,

33.verse: and we saw some of the Anakim there, descendants of the ancient race of giants. We felt like grasshoppers before them, they were so tall!”

1.verse: Then all the people began weeping aloud, and they carried on all night.

2.verse: Their voices rose in a great chorus of complaint against Moses and Aaron. “We wish we had died in Egypt,” they wailed, “or even here in the wilderness,

3.verse: rather than be taken into this country ahead of us. Jehovah will kill us there, and our wives and little ones will become slaves. Let’s get out of here and return to Egypt!”

4.verse: The idea swept the camp. “Let’s elect a leader to take us back to Egypt!” they shouted.

5.verse: Then Moses and Aaron fell face downward on the ground before the people of Israel.

6.verse: Two of the spies, Joshua (the son of Nun), and Caleb (the son of Jephunneh), ripped their clothing

7.verse: and said to all the people, “It is a wonderful country ahead,

8.verse: and the Lord loves us. He will bring us safely into the land and give it to us. It is very fertile, a land ‘flowing with milk and honey’!

9.verse: Oh, do not rebel against the Lord, and do not fear the people of the land. For they are but bread for us to eat! The Lord is with us and he has removed his protection from them! Don’t be afraid of them!”

10.verse: But the only response of the people was to talk of stoning them. Then the glory of the Lord appeared, and the Lord said to Moses, “How long will these people despise me? Will they never believe me, even after all the miracles I have done among them?

11.verse: But the only response of the people was to talk of stoning them. Then the glory of the Lord appeared, and the Lord said to Moses, “How long will these people despise me? Will they never believe me, even after all the miracles I have done among them?

12.verse: I will disinherit them and destroy them with a plague, and I will make you into a nation far greater and mightier than they are!”

13.verse: “But what will the Egyptians think when they hear about it?” Moses pleaded with the Lord. “They know full well the power you displayed in rescuing your people.

14.verse: They have told this to the inhabitants of this land, who are well aware that you are with Israel and that you talk with her face-to-face. They see the pillar of cloud and fire standing above us, and they know that you lead and protect us day and night.

15.verse: Now if you kill all your people, the nations that have heard your fame will say,

16.verse: ‘The Lord had to kill them because he wasn’t able to take care of them in the wilderness. He wasn’t strong enough to bring them into the land he swore he would give them.’

17.verse: “Oh, please, show the great power of your patience by forgiving our sins and showing us your steadfast love. Forgive us, even though you have said that you don’t let sin go unpunished, and that you punish the father’s fault in the children to the third and fourth generation.

18.verse: “Oh, please, show the great power of your patience by forgiving our sins and showing us your steadfast love. Forgive us, even though you have said that you don’t let sin go unpunished, and that you punish the father’s fault in the children to the third and fourth generation.

19.verse: Oh, I plead with you, pardon the sins of this people because of your magnificent, steadfast love, just as you have forgiven them all the time from when we left Egypt until now.”

20.verse: Then the Lord said, “All right, I will pardon them as you have requested. But I vow by my own name that just as it is true that all the earth shall be filled with the glory of the Lord,

21.verse: Then the Lord said, “All right, I will pardon them as you have requested. But I vow by my own name that just as it is true that all the earth shall be filled with the glory of the Lord,

22.verse: so it is true that not one of the men who has seen my glory and the miracles I did both in Egypt and in the wilderness—and ten times refused to trust me and obey me—

23.verse: shall even see the land I promised to this people’s ancestors.

24.verse: But my servant Caleb is a different kind of man—he has obeyed me fully. I will bring him into the land he entered as a spy, and his descendants shall have their full share in it.

25.verse: But now, since the people of Israel are so afraid of the Amalekites and the Canaanites living in the valleys, tomorrow you must turn back into the wilderness in the direction of the Red Sea.”

26.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses and to Aaron, “How long will this wicked nation complain about me? For I have heard all that they have been saying.

27.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses and to Aaron, “How long will this wicked nation complain about me? For I have heard all that they have been saying.

28.verse: Tell them, ‘The Lord vows to do to you what you feared:

29.verse: You will all die here in this wilderness! Not a single one of you twenty years old and older, who has complained against me,

30.verse: shall enter the Promised Land. Only Caleb (son of Jephunneh) and Joshua (son of Nun) are permitted to enter it.

31.verse: “‘You said your children would become slaves of the people of the land. Well, instead I will bring them safely into the land and they shall inherit what you have despised.

32.verse: But as for you, your dead bodies shall fall in this wilderness.

33.verse: You must wander in the desert like nomads for forty years. In this way you will pay for your faithlessness, until the last of you lies dead in the desert.

34.verse: “‘Since the spies were in the land for forty days, you must wander in the wilderness for forty years—a year for each day, bearing the burden of your sins. I will teach you what it means to reject me. I, Jehovah, have spoken. Every one of you who has conspired against me shall die here in this wilderness.’”

35.verse: “‘Since the spies were in the land for forty days, you must wander in the wilderness for forty years—a year for each day, bearing the burden of your sins. I will teach you what it means to reject me. I, Jehovah, have spoken. Every one of you who has conspired against me shall die here in this wilderness.’”

36.verse: Then the ten spies who had incited the rebellion against Jehovah by striking fear into the hearts of the people were struck dead before the Lord. Of all the spies, only Joshua and Caleb remained alive.

37.verse: Then the ten spies who had incited the rebellion against Jehovah by striking fear into the hearts of the people were struck dead before the Lord. Of all the spies, only Joshua and Caleb remained alive.

38.verse: Then the ten spies who had incited the rebellion against Jehovah by striking fear into the hearts of the people were struck dead before the Lord. Of all the spies, only Joshua and Caleb remained alive.

39.verse: What sorrow there was throughout the camp when Moses reported God’s words to the people!

40.verse: They were up early the next morning and started toward the Promised Land. “Here we are!” they said. “We realize that we have sinned, but now we are ready to go on into the land the Lord has promised us.”

41.verse: But Moses said, “It’s too late. Now you are disobeying the Lord’s orders to return to the wilderness.

42.verse: Don’t go ahead with your plan or you will be crushed by your enemies, for the Lord is not with you.

43.verse: Don’t you remember? The Amalekites and the Canaanites are there! You have deserted the Lord, and now he will desert you.”

44.verse: But they went ahead into the hill country, despite the fact that neither the Ark nor Moses left the camp.

45.verse: Then the Amalekites and the Canaanites who lived in the hills came down and attacked them and chased them to Hormah.

1.verse: The Lord told Moses to give these instructions to the people of Israel: “When your children finally live in the land I am going to give them,

2.verse: The Lord told Moses to give these instructions to the people of Israel: “When your children finally live in the land I am going to give them,

3.verse: and they want to please the Lord with a burnt offering or any other offering by fire, their sacrifice must be an animal from their flocks of sheep and goats, or from their herds of cattle. Each sacrifice—whether an ordinary one, or a sacrifice to fulfill a vow, or a freewill offering, or a special sacrifice at any of the annual festivals—must be accompanied by a grain offering. If a lamb is being sacrificed, use three quarts of fine flour mixed with three pints of oil,

4.verse: and they want to please the Lord with a burnt offering or any other offering by fire, their sacrifice must be an animal from their flocks of sheep and goats, or from their herds of cattle. Each sacrifice—whether an ordinary one, or a sacrifice to fulfill a vow, or a freewill offering, or a special sacrifice at any of the annual festivals—must be accompanied by a grain offering. If a lamb is being sacrificed, use three quarts of fine flour mixed with three pints of oil,

5.verse: accompanied by three pints of wine for a drink offering.

6.verse: “If the sacrifice is a ram, use six quarts of fine flour mixed with four pints of oil,

7.verse: and four pints of wine for a drink offering. This will be a sacrifice that is a pleasing fragrance to the Lord.

8.verse: “If the sacrifice is a young bull, then the grain offering accompanying it must consist of nine quarts of fine flour mixed with three quarts of oil,

9.verse: “If the sacrifice is a young bull, then the grain offering accompanying it must consist of nine quarts of fine flour mixed with three quarts of oil,

10.verse: plus three quarts of wine for the drink offering. This shall be offered by fire as a pleasing fragrance to the Lord.

11.verse: “These are the instructions for what is to accompany each sacrificial bull, ram, lamb, or young goat.

12.verse: “These are the instructions for what is to accompany each sacrificial bull, ram, lamb, or young goat.

13.verse: These instructions apply both to native-born Israelis and to foreigners living among you who want to please the Lord with sacrifices offered by fire;

14.verse: These instructions apply both to native-born Israelis and to foreigners living among you who want to please the Lord with sacrifices offered by fire;

15.verse: for there is the same law for all, native-born or foreigner, and this shall be true forever from generation to generation; all are the same before the Lord. Yes, one law for all!”

16.verse: for there is the same law for all, native-born or foreigner, and this shall be true forever from generation to generation; all are the same before the Lord. Yes, one law for all!”

17.verse: The Lord also said to Moses at this time, “Instruct the people of Israel that when they arrive in the land that I am going to give them,

18.verse: The Lord also said to Moses at this time, “Instruct the people of Israel that when they arrive in the land that I am going to give them,

19.verse: they must present to the Lord a sample of each year’s new crops by making a loaf, using coarse flour from the first grain that is cut each year. This loaf must be waved back and forth before the altar in a gesture of offering to the Lord. It is an annual offering from your threshing floor and must be observed from generation to generation.

20.verse: they must present to the Lord a sample of each year’s new crops by making a loaf, using coarse flour from the first grain that is cut each year. This loaf must be waved back and forth before the altar in a gesture of offering to the Lord. It is an annual offering from your threshing floor and must be observed from generation to generation.

21.verse: they must present to the Lord a sample of each year’s new crops by making a loaf, using coarse flour from the first grain that is cut each year. This loaf must be waved back and forth before the altar in a gesture of offering to the Lord. It is an annual offering from your threshing floor and must be observed from generation to generation.

22.verse: “If by mistake you or future generations fail to carry out all of these regulations that the Lord has given you over the years through Moses,

23.verse: then when the people realize their error, they must offer one young bull for a burnt offering. It will be a pleasant odor before the Lord, and must be offered along with the usual grain offering and drink offering, and one male goat for a sin offering.

24.verse: then when the people realize their error, they must offer one young bull for a burnt offering. It will be a pleasant odor before the Lord, and must be offered along with the usual grain offering and drink offering, and one male goat for a sin offering.

25.verse: And the priest shall make atonement for all of the people of Israel and they shall be forgiven; for it was an error, and they have corrected it with their sacrifice made by fire before the Lord, and by their sin offering.

26.verse: All the people shall be forgiven, including the foreigners living among them, for the entire population is involved in such error and forgiveness.

27.verse: “If the error is made by a single individual, then he shall sacrifice a one-year-old female goat for a sin offering,

28.verse: and the priest shall make atonement for him before the Lord, and he shall be forgiven.

29.verse: This same law applies to individual foreigners who are living among you.

30.verse: “But anyone who deliberately makes the ‘mistake,’ whether he is a native Israeli or a foreigner, is blaspheming Jehovah, and shall be cut off from among his people.

31.verse: For he has despised the commandment of the Lord and deliberately failed to obey his law; he must be executed and die in his sin.”

32.verse: One day while the people of Israel were in the wilderness, one of them was caught gathering wood on the Sabbath day.

33.verse: He was arrested and taken before Moses and Aaron and the other judges.

34.verse: They jailed him until they could find out the Lord’s mind concerning him.

35.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “The man must die—all the people shall stone him to death outside the camp.”

36.verse: So they took him outside the camp and killed him as the Lord had commanded.

37.verse: The Lord said to Moses, “Tell the people of Israel to make tassels for the hems of their clothes (this is a permanent regulation from generation to generation) and to attach the tassels to their clothes with a blue cord.

38.verse: The Lord said to Moses, “Tell the people of Israel to make tassels for the hems of their clothes (this is a permanent regulation from generation to generation) and to attach the tassels to their clothes with a blue cord.

39.verse: The purpose of this regulation is to remind you, whenever you notice the tassels, of the commandments of the Lord, and that you are to obey his laws instead of following your own desires and going your own ways, as you used to do in serving other gods.

40.verse: It will remind you to be holy to your God.

41.verse: For I am Jehovah your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt; yes, I am the Lord, your God.”

1.verse: One day Korah (son of Izhar, grandson of Kohath, and a descendant of Levi) conspired with Dathan and Abiram (the sons of Eliab) and On (the son of Peleth), all three from the tribe of Reuben,

2.verse: to incite a rebellion against Moses. Two hundred and fifty popular leaders, all members of the Assembly, were involved.

3.verse: They went to Moses and Aaron and said, “We have had enough of your presumption; you are no better than anyone else; everyone in Israel has been chosen of the Lord, and he is with all of us. What right do you have to put yourselves forward, claiming that we must obey you, and acting as though you were greater than anyone else among all these people of the Lord?”

4.verse: When Moses heard what they were saying he fell face downward to the ground.

5.verse: Then he said to Korah and to those who were with him, “In the morning the Lord will show you who are his, and who is holy, and whom he has chosen as his priest.

6.verse: Do this: You, Korah, and all those with you, take censers tomorrow and light them, and put incense upon them before the Lord, and we will find out whom the Lord has chosen. You are the presumptuous ones, you sons of Levi.”

7.verse: Do this: You, Korah, and all those with you, take censers tomorrow and light them, and put incense upon them before the Lord, and we will find out whom the Lord has chosen. You are the presumptuous ones, you sons of Levi.”

8.verse: Then Moses spoke again to Korah: “Does it seem a small thing to you that the God of Israel has chosen you from among all the people of Israel to be near to himself as you work in the Tabernacle of Jehovah, and to stand before the people to minister to them?

9.verse: Then Moses spoke again to Korah: “Does it seem a small thing to you that the God of Israel has chosen you from among all the people of Israel to be near to himself as you work in the Tabernacle of Jehovah, and to stand before the people to minister to them?

10.verse: Is it nothing to you that he has given this task to only you Levites? And now are you demanding the priesthood also?

11.verse: That is what you are really after! That is why you are revolting against Jehovah. And what has Aaron done, that you are dissatisfied with him?” Then Moses summoned Dathan and Abiram (the sons of Eliab), but they refused to come.

12.verse: That is what you are really after! That is why you are revolting against Jehovah. And what has Aaron done, that you are dissatisfied with him?” Then Moses summoned Dathan and Abiram (the sons of Eliab), but they refused to come.

13.verse: “Is it a small thing,” they mimicked, “that you brought us out of lovely Egypt to kill us here in this terrible wilderness, and that now you want to make yourself our king?

14.verse: What’s more, you haven’t brought us into the wonderful country you promised, nor given us fields and vineyards. Whom are you trying to fool? We refuse to come.”

15.verse: Then Moses was very angry and said to the Lord, “Do not accept their sacrifices! I have never stolen so much as a donkey from them and have not hurt one of them.”

16.verse: And Moses said to Korah, “Come here tomorrow before the Lord with all your friends; Aaron will be here too.

17.verse: Be sure to bring your censers with incense on them; a censer for each man, 250 in all; and Aaron will also be here with his.”

18.verse: So they did. They came with their censers and lit them and placed the incense on them, and stood at the entrance of the Tabernacle with Moses and Aaron.

19.verse: Meanwhile, Korah had stirred up the entire nation against Moses and Aaron, and they all assembled to watch. Then the glory of Jehovah appeared to all the people,

20.verse: and Jehovah said to Moses and Aaron,

21.verse: “Get away from these people so that I may instantly destroy them.”

22.verse: But Moses and Aaron fell face downward to the ground before the Lord. “O God, the God of all mankind,” they pleaded, “must you be angry with all the people when one man sins?”

23.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “Then tell the people to get away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.”

24.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “Then tell the people to get away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.”

25.verse: So Moses rushed over to the tents of Dathan and Abiram, followed closely by the 250 Israeli leaders.

26.verse: “Quick!” he told the people, “get away from the tents of these wicked men, and don’t touch anything that belongs to them, lest you be included in their sins and be destroyed with them.”

27.verse: So all the people stood back from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. And Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the entrances of their tents with their wives and sons and little ones.

28.verse: And Moses said, “By this you shall know that Jehovah has sent me to do all these things that I have done—for I have not done them on my own.

29.verse: If these men die a natural death or from some ordinary accident or disease, then Jehovah has not sent me.

30.verse: But if the Lord does a miracle and the ground opens up and swallows them and everything that belongs to them, and they go down alive into Sheol, then you will know that these men have despised the Lord.”

31.verse: He had hardly finished speaking the words when the ground suddenly split open beneath them,

32.verse: and a great fissure swallowed them up, along with their tents and families and the friends who were standing with them, and everything they owned.

33.verse: So they went down alive into Sheol and the earth closed upon them, and they perished.

34.verse: All of the people of Israel fled at their screams, fearing that the earth would swallow them too.

35.verse: Then fire came from Jehovah and burned up the 250 men who were offering incense.

36.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest to pull those censers from the fire; for they are holy, dedicated to the Lord. He must also scatter the burning incense

37.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest to pull those censers from the fire; for they are holy, dedicated to the Lord. He must also scatter the burning incense

38.verse: from the censers of these men who have sinned at the cost of their lives. He shall then beat the metal into a sheet as a covering for the altar, for these censers are holy because they were used before the Lord; and the altar sheet shall be a reminder to the people of Israel.”

39.verse: So Eleazar the priest took the 250 bronze censers and beat them out into a sheet of metal to cover the altar,

40.verse: to be a reminder to the people of Israel that no unauthorized person—no one who is not a descendant of Aaron—may come before the Lord to burn incense, lest the same thing happen to him as happened to Korah and his associates. Thus the Lord’s directions to Moses were carried out.

41.verse: But the very next morning all the people began muttering again against Moses and Aaron, saying, “You have killed the Lord’s people.”

42.verse: Soon a great, sullen mob formed; suddenly, as they looked toward the Tabernacle, the Cloud appeared and the awesome glory of the Lord was seen.

43.verse: Moses and Aaron came and stood at the entrance of the Tabernacle, and the Lord said to Moses,

44.verse: Moses and Aaron came and stood at the entrance of the Tabernacle, and the Lord said to Moses,

45.verse: “Get away from these people so that I can instantly destroy them.” But Moses and Aaron fell face downward to the earth before the Lord.

46.verse: And Moses said to Aaron, “Quick, take a censer and place fire in it from the altar; lay incense on it, and carry it quickly among the people and make atonement for them; for God’s anger has gone out among them—the plague has already begun.”

47.verse: Aaron did as Moses had told him to, and ran among the people, for the plague had indeed already begun; and he put on the incense and made atonement for them.

48.verse: And he stood between the living and the dead, and the plague was stopped,

49.verse: but not before 14,700 people had died (in addition to those who had died the previous day with Korah).

50.verse: Then Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance of the Tabernacle; and so the plague was stopped.

1.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell the people of Israel that each of their tribal chiefs is to bring you a wooden rod with his name inscribed upon it. Aaron’s name is to be on the rod of the tribe of Levi.

2.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell the people of Israel that each of their tribal chiefs is to bring you a wooden rod with his name inscribed upon it. Aaron’s name is to be on the rod of the tribe of Levi.

3.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell the people of Israel that each of their tribal chiefs is to bring you a wooden rod with his name inscribed upon it. Aaron’s name is to be on the rod of the tribe of Levi.

4.verse: Put these rods in the inner room of the Tabernacle where I meet with you, in front of the Ark.

5.verse: I will use these rods to identify the man I have chosen: for buds will grow on his rod! Then at last this murmuring and complaining against you will stop!”

6.verse: So Moses gave the instructions to the people, and each of the twelve chiefs (including Aaron) brought him a rod.

7.verse: He put them before the Lord in the inner room of the Tabernacle,

8.verse: and when he went in the next day, he found that Aaron’s rod, representing the tribe of Levi, had budded and was blossoming, and had ripe almonds hanging from it!

9.verse: When Moses brought them out to show the others, they stared in disbelief! Then each man except Aaron claimed his rod.

10.verse: The Lord told Moses to place Aaron’s rod permanently beside the Ark as a reminder of this rebellion. He was to bring it out and show it to the people again if there were any further complaints about Aaron’s authority; this would ward off further catastrophe to the people.

11.verse: So Moses did as the Lord commanded him.

12.verse: But the people of Israel only grumbled the more. “We are as good as dead,” they whined. “Everyone who even comes close to the Tabernacle dies. Must we all perish?”

13.verse: But the people of Israel only grumbled the more. “We are as good as dead,” they whined. “Everyone who even comes close to the Tabernacle dies. Must we all perish?”

1.verse: The Lord now spoke to Aaron: “You and your sons and your family are responsible for any desecration of the sanctuary,” he said, “and will be held liable for any impropriety in your priestly work.

2.verse: “Your kinsmen, the tribe of Levi, are your assistants; but only you and your sons may perform the sacred duties in the Tabernacle itself. The Levites must be careful not to touch any of the sacred articles or the altar, lest I destroy both them and you.

3.verse: “Your kinsmen, the tribe of Levi, are your assistants; but only you and your sons may perform the sacred duties in the Tabernacle itself. The Levites must be careful not to touch any of the sacred articles or the altar, lest I destroy both them and you.

4.verse: No one who is not a member of the tribe of Levi shall assist you in any way.

5.verse: Remember, only the priests are to perform the sacred duties within the sanctuary and at the altar. If you follow these instructions, the wrath of God will never again fall upon any of the people of Israel for violating this law.

6.verse: I say it again—your kinsmen the Levites are your assistants for the work of the Tabernacle. They are a gift to you from the Lord.

7.verse: But you and your sons, the priests, shall personally handle all the sacred service, including the altar and all that is within the veil, for the priesthood is your special gift of service. Anyone else who attempts to perform these duties shall die.”

8.verse: The Lord gave these further instructions to Aaron: “I have given the priests all the gifts which are brought to the Lord by the people; all these offerings presented to the Lord by the gesture of waving them before the altar belong to you and your sons, by permanent law.

9.verse: The grain offerings, the sin offerings, and the guilt offerings are yours, except for the sample presented to the Lord by burning upon the altar. All these are most holy offerings.

10.verse: They are to be eaten only in a most holy place, and only by males.

11.verse: All other gifts presented to me by the gesture of waving them before the altar are for you and your families, sons and daughters alike. For all the members of your families may eat these unless anyone is ceremonially impure at the time.

12.verse: “Yours also are the first-of-the-harvest gifts the people bring as offerings to the Lord—the best of the olive oil, wine, grain,

13.verse: and every other crop. Your families may eat these unless they are ceremonially defiled at the time.

14.verse: So everything that is dedicated to the Lord shall be yours, including the firstborn sons of the people of Israel, and the firstborn of their animals.

15.verse: So everything that is dedicated to the Lord shall be yours, including the firstborn sons of the people of Israel, and the firstborn of their animals.

16.verse: However, you may never accept the firstborn sons, nor the firstborn of any animals that I do not permit for food. Instead, there must be a payment of two and a half dollars made for each firstborn child. It is to be brought when he is one month old.

17.verse: “However, the firstborn of cows, sheep, or goats may not be bought back; they must be sacrificed to the Lord. Their blood is to be sprinkled upon the altar, and their fat shall be burned as a fire offering; it is very pleasant to the Lord.

18.verse: The meat of these animals shall be yours, including the breast and right thigh that are presented to the Lord by the gesture of waving before the altar.

19.verse: Yes, I have given to you all of these ‘wave offerings’ brought by the people of Israel to the Lord; they are for you and your families as food; this is a permanent contract between the Lord and you and your descendants.

20.verse: “You priests may own no property nor have any other income, for I am all that you need.

21.verse: “As for the tribe of Levi, your relatives, they shall be paid for their service with the tithes from the entire land of Israel.

22.verse: “From now on, Israelites other than the priests and Levites shall not enter the sanctuary lest they be judged guilty and die.

23.verse: Only the Levites shall do the work there, and they shall be guilty if they fail. This is a permanent law among you, that the Levites shall own no property in Israel,

24.verse: for the people’s tithes, offered to the Lord by the gesture of waving before the altar, shall belong to the Levites; these are their inheritance, and so they have no need for property.”

25.verse: The Lord also said to Moses, “Tell the Levites to give to the Lord a tenth of the tithes they receive—a tithe of the tithe, to be presented to the Lord by the gesture of waving before the altar.

26.verse: The Lord also said to Moses, “Tell the Levites to give to the Lord a tenth of the tithes they receive—a tithe of the tithe, to be presented to the Lord by the gesture of waving before the altar.

27.verse: The Lord will consider this as your first-of-the-harvest offering to him of grain and wine, as though it were from your own property.

28.verse: This tithe of the tithe shall be selected from the choicest part of the tithes you receive as the Lord’s portion, and shall be given to Aaron the priest.

29.verse: This tithe of the tithe shall be selected from the choicest part of the tithes you receive as the Lord’s portion, and shall be given to Aaron the priest.

30.verse: It shall be credited to you just as though it were from your own threshing floor and winepress.

31.verse: Aaron and his sons and their families may eat it in their homes or anywhere they wish, for it is their compensation for their service in the Tabernacle.

32.verse: You Levites will not be held guilty for accepting the Lord’s tithes if you then give the best tenth to the priests. But beware that you do not treat the holy gifts of the people of Israel as though they were common, lest you die.”

1.verse: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Here is another of my laws: Tell the people of Israel to bring you a red heifer without defect, one that has never been yoked. Give her to Eleazar the priest and he shall take her outside the camp and someone shall kill her as he watches.

2.verse: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Here is another of my laws: Tell the people of Israel to bring you a red heifer without defect, one that has never been yoked. Give her to Eleazar the priest and he shall take her outside the camp and someone shall kill her as he watches.

3.verse: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Here is another of my laws: Tell the people of Israel to bring you a red heifer without defect, one that has never been yoked. Give her to Eleazar the priest and he shall take her outside the camp and someone shall kill her as he watches.

4.verse: Eleazar shall take some of her blood upon his finger and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the Tabernacle.

5.verse: Then someone shall burn the heifer as he watches—her hide, meat, blood, and dung.

6.verse: Eleazar shall take cedar wood and hyssop branches and scarlet thread, and throw them into the burning pile.

7.verse: “Then he must wash his clothes, and bathe, and afterwards return to the camp and be ceremonially defiled until the evening.

8.verse: And the one who burns the animal must wash his clothes and bathe, and he too shall be defiled until evening.

9.verse: Then someone who is not ceremonially defiled shall gather up the ashes of the heifer and place them in some purified place outside the camp, where they shall be kept for the people of Israel as a source of water for the purification ceremonies, for removal of sin.

10.verse: And the one who gathers up the ashes of the heifer must wash his clothes and be defiled until evening; this is a permanent law for the benefit of the people of Israel and any foreigners living among them.

11.verse: “Anyone who touches a dead human body shall be defiled for seven days,

12.verse: and must purify himself the third and seventh days with water run through the ashes of the red heifer; then he will be purified; but if he does not do this on the third day, he will continue to be defiled even after the seventh day.

13.verse: Anyone who touches a dead person and does not purify himself in the manner specified has defiled the Tabernacle of the Lord, and shall be excommunicated from Israel. The cleansing water was not sprinkled upon him, so the defilement continues.

14.verse: “When a man dies in a tent, these are the various regulations: Everyone who enters the tent, and those who are in it at the time, shall be defiled seven days.

15.verse: Any container in the tent without a lid over it is defiled.

16.verse: “If someone out in a field touches the corpse of someone who has been killed in battle or who has died in any other way, or if he even touches a bone or a grave, he shall be defiled seven days.

17.verse: To become purified again, ashes from the red heifer sin offering are to be added to spring water in a kettle.

18.verse: Then a person who is not defiled shall take hyssop branches and dip them into the water and sprinkle the water upon the tent and upon all the pots and pans in the tent, and upon anyone who has been defiled by being in the tent, or by touching a bone, or touching someone who has been killed or is otherwise dead, or has touched a grave.

19.verse: This shall take place on the third and seventh days; then the defiled person must wash his clothes and bathe himself, and that evening he will be out from under the defilement.

20.verse: “But anyone who is defiled and doesn’t purify himself shall be excommunicated, for he has defiled the sanctuary of the Lord, and the water to cleanse him has not been sprinkled upon him; so he remains defiled.

21.verse: This is a permanent law. The man who sprinkles the water must afterwards wash his clothes; and anyone touching the water shall be defiled until evening.

22.verse: And anything a defiled person touches shall be defiled until evening.”

1.verse: The people of Israel arrived in the wilderness of Zin in April and camped at Kadesh, where Miriam died and was buried.

2.verse: There was not enough water to drink at that place, so the people again rebelled against Moses and Aaron. A great mob formed,

3.verse: and they held a protest meeting. “Would that we too had died with our dear brothers the Lord killed!” they shouted at Moses.

4.verse: “You have deliberately brought us into this wilderness to get rid of us, along with our flocks and herds.

5.verse: Why did you ever make us leave Egypt and bring us here to this evil place? Where is the fertile land of wonderful crops—the figs, vines, and pomegranates you told us about? Why, there isn’t even water enough to drink!”

6.verse: Moses and Aaron turned away and went to the entrance of the Tabernacle, where they fell face downward before the Lord; and the glory of Jehovah appeared to them.

7.verse: And he said to Moses,

8.verse: “Get Aaron’s rod; then you and Aaron must summon the people. As they watch, speak to that rock over there and tell it to pour out its water! You will give them water from a rock, enough for all the people and all their cattle!”

9.verse: So Moses did as instructed. He took the rod from the place where it was kept before the Lord;

10.verse: then Moses and Aaron summoned the people to come and gather at the rock; and he said to them, “Listen, you rebels! Must we bring you water from this rock?”

11.verse: Then Moses lifted the rod and struck the rock twice, and water gushed out; and the people and their cattle drank.

12.verse: But the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not believe me and did not sanctify me in the eyes of the people of Israel, you shall not bring them into the land I have promised them!”

13.verse: This place was named Meribah (meaning “Rebel Waters”), because it was where the people of Israel fought against Jehovah, and where he showed himself to be holy before them.

14.verse: While Moses was at Kadesh he sent messengers to the king of Edom: “We are the descendants of your brother, Israel,” he declared. “You know our sad history,

15.verse: how our ancestors went down to visit Egypt and stayed there so long, and became slaves of the Egyptians.

16.verse: But when we cried to the Lord he heard us and sent an Angel who brought us out of Egypt, and now we are here at Kadesh, encamped on the borders of your land.

17.verse: Please let us pass through your country. We will be careful not to go through your planted fields, nor through your vineyards; we won’t even drink water from your wells, but will stay on the main road and not leave it until we have crossed your border on the other side.”

18.verse: But the king of Edom said, “Stay out! If you attempt to enter my land, I will meet you with an army!”

19.verse: “But, sir,” protested the Israeli ambassadors, “we will stay on the main road and will not even drink your water unless we pay whatever you demand for it. We only want to pass through and nothing else.”

20.verse: But the king of Edom was adamant. “Stay out!” he warned, and, mobilizing his army, he marched to the frontier with a great force.

21.verse: Because Edom refused to allow Israel to pass through their country, Israel turned back and journeyed from Kadesh to Mount Hor.

22.verse: Because Edom refused to allow Israel to pass through their country, Israel turned back and journeyed from Kadesh to Mount Hor.

23.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron at the border of the land of Edom,

24.verse: “The time has come for Aaron to die—for he shall not enter the land I have given the people of Israel, for the two of you rebelled against my instructions concerning the water at Meribah.

25.verse: Now take Aaron and his son Eleazar and lead them up onto Mount Hor.

26.verse: There you shall remove Aaron’s priestly garments from him and put them on Eleazar his son; and Aaron shall die there.”

27.verse: So Moses did as the Lord commanded him. The three of them went up together into Mount Hor as all the people watched.

28.verse: When they reached the summit, Moses removed the priestly garments from Aaron and put them on his son Eleazar; and Aaron died on the top of the mountain. Moses and Eleazar returned,

29.verse: and when the people were informed of Aaron’s death, they mourned for him for thirty days.

1.verse: When the king of Arad heard that the Israelis were approaching (for they were traveling the same route as the spies), he mobilized his army and attacked Israel, taking some of the men as prisoners.

2.verse: Then the people of Israel vowed to the Lord that if he would help them conquer the king of Arad and his people, they would completely annihilate all the cities of that area.

3.verse: The Lord heeded their request and defeated the Canaanites; and the Israelis completely destroyed them and their cities. The name of the region was thereafter called Hormah (meaning “Utterly Destroyed”).

4.verse: Then the people of Israel returned to Mount Hor, and from there continued southward along the road to the Red Sea in order to go around the land of Edom. The people were very discouraged;

5.verse: they began to murmur against God and to complain against Moses. “Why have you brought us out of Egypt to die here in the wilderness?” they whined. “There is nothing to eat here, and nothing to drink, and we hate this insipid manna.”

6.verse: So the Lord sent poisonous snakes among them to punish them, and many of them were bitten and died.

7.verse: Then the people came to Moses and cried out, “We have sinned, for we have spoken against Jehovah and against you. Pray to him to take away the snakes.” So Moses prayed for the people.

8.verse: Then the Lord told him, “Make a bronze replica of one of these snakes and attach it to the top of a pole; anyone who is bitten shall live if he simply looks at it!”

9.verse: So Moses made the replica, and whenever anyone who had been bitten looked at the bronze snake, he recovered!

10.verse: Israel journeyed next to Oboth and camped there.

11.verse: Then they went on to Iyeabarim, in the wilderness, a short distance east of Moab,

12.verse: and from there they traveled to the valley of the brook Zared and set up camp.

13.verse: Then they moved to the far side of the Arnon River, near the borders of the Amorites. (The Arnon River is the boundary line between the Moabites and the Amorites.

14.verse: This fact is mentioned in The Book of the Wars of Jehovah, where it is stated that the valley of the Arnon River and the city of Waheb

15.verse: lie between the Amorites and the people of Moab.)

16.verse: Then Israel traveled to Beer (meaning “A Well”). This is the place where the Lord told Moses, “Summon the people, and I will give them water.”

17.verse: What happened is described in this song the people sang: Spring up, O well! Sing of the water! This is a well The leaders dug. It was hollowed With their staves And shovels. Then they left the desert and proceeded on through Mattanah,

18.verse: What happened is described in this song the people sang: Spring up, O well! Sing of the water! This is a well The leaders dug. It was hollowed With their staves And shovels. Then they left the desert and proceeded on through Mattanah,

19.verse: Nahaliel, and Bamoth;

20.verse: then to the valley in the plateau of Moab, which overlooks the desert with Mount Pisgah in the distance.

21.verse: Israel now sent ambassadors to King Sihon of the Amorites.

22.verse: “Let us travel through your land,” they requested. “We will not leave the road until we have passed beyond your borders. We won’t trample your fields or touch your vineyards or drink your water.”

23.verse: But King Sihon refused. Instead he mobilized his army and attacked Israel in the wilderness, battling them at Jahaz.

24.verse: But Israel slaughtered them and occupied their land from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River, as far as the borders of the Ammonites; but they were stopped there by the rugged terrain.

25.verse: So Israel captured all the cities of the Amorites and lived in them, including the city of Heshbon, which had been King Sihon’s capital.

26.verse: So Israel captured all the cities of the Amorites and lived in them, including the city of Heshbon, which had been King Sihon’s capital.

27.verse: The ancient poets had referred to King Sihon in this poem: Come to Heshbon, King Sihon’s capital, For a fire has flamed forth And devoured The city of Ar in Moab, On the heights of the Arnon River. Woe to Moab! You are finished, O people of Chemosh; Your sons have fled, And your daughters are captured By King Sihon of the Amorites. He has destroyed The little children And the men and women As far as Dibon, Nophah, and Medeba.

28.verse: The ancient poets had referred to King Sihon in this poem: Come to Heshbon, King Sihon’s capital, For a fire has flamed forth And devoured The city of Ar in Moab, On the heights of the Arnon River. Woe to Moab! You are finished, O people of Chemosh; Your sons have fled, And your daughters are captured By King Sihon of the Amorites. He has destroyed The little children And the men and women As far as Dibon, Nophah, and Medeba.

29.verse: The ancient poets had referred to King Sihon in this poem: Come to Heshbon, King Sihon’s capital, For a fire has flamed forth And devoured The city of Ar in Moab, On the heights of the Arnon River. Woe to Moab! You are finished, O people of Chemosh; Your sons have fled, And your daughters are captured By King Sihon of the Amorites. He has destroyed The little children And the men and women As far as Dibon, Nophah, and Medeba.

30.verse: The ancient poets had referred to King Sihon in this poem: Come to Heshbon, King Sihon’s capital, For a fire has flamed forth And devoured The city of Ar in Moab, On the heights of the Arnon River. Woe to Moab! You are finished, O people of Chemosh; Your sons have fled, And your daughters are captured By King Sihon of the Amorites. He has destroyed The little children And the men and women As far as Dibon, Nophah, and Medeba.

31.verse: While Israel was there in the Amorite country, Moses sent spies to look over the Jazer area; he followed up with an armed attack, capturing all of the towns and driving out the Amorites.

32.verse: While Israel was there in the Amorite country, Moses sent spies to look over the Jazer area; he followed up with an armed attack, capturing all of the towns and driving out the Amorites.

33.verse: They next turned their attention to the city of Bashan, but King Og of Bashan met them with his army at Edrei.

34.verse: The Lord told Moses not to fear—that the enemy was already conquered! “The same thing will happen to King Og as happened to King Sihon at Heshbon,” the Lord assured him.

35.verse: And sure enough, Israel was victorious and killed King Og, his sons, and his subjects, so that not a single survivor remained; and Israel occupied the land.

1.verse: The people of Israel now traveled to the plains of Moab and camped east of the Jordan River opposite Jericho.

2.verse: When King Balak of Moab (the son of Zippor) realized how many of them there were, and when he learned what they had done to the Amorites, he and his people were terrified.

3.verse: When King Balak of Moab (the son of Zippor) realized how many of them there were, and when he learned what they had done to the Amorites, he and his people were terrified.

4.verse: They quickly consulted with the leaders of Midian. “This mob will eat us like an ox eats grass,” they exclaimed. So King Balak

5.verse: sent messengers to Balaam (son of Beor) who was living in his native land of Pethor, near the Euphrates River. He begged Balaam to come and help him. “A vast horde of people has arrived from Egypt, and they cover the face of the earth and are headed toward me,” he frantically explained. “Please come and curse them for me, so that I can drive them out of my land; for I know what fantastic blessings fall on those whom you bless, and I also know that those whom you curse are doomed.”

6.verse: sent messengers to Balaam (son of Beor) who was living in his native land of Pethor, near the Euphrates River. He begged Balaam to come and help him. “A vast horde of people has arrived from Egypt, and they cover the face of the earth and are headed toward me,” he frantically explained. “Please come and curse them for me, so that I can drive them out of my land; for I know what fantastic blessings fall on those whom you bless, and I also know that those whom you curse are doomed.”

7.verse: The messengers he sent were some of the top leaders of Moab and Midian. They went to Balaam with money in hand and urgently explained to him what Balak wanted.

8.verse: “Stay here overnight,” Balaam said, “and I’ll tell you in the morning whatever the Lord directs me to say.” So they did.

9.verse: That night God came to Balaam and asked him, “Who are these men?”

10.verse: “They have come from King Balak of Moab,” he replied.

11.verse: “The king says that a vast horde of people from Egypt has arrived at his border, and he wants me to go at once and curse them, in the hope that he can battle them successfully.”

12.verse: “Don’t do it!” God told him. “You are not to curse them, for I have blessed them!”

13.verse: The next morning Balaam told the men, “Go on home! The Lord won’t let me do it.”

14.verse: So King Balak’s ambassadors returned without him and reported his refusal.

15.verse: Balak tried again. This time he sent a larger number of even more distinguished ambassadors than the former group.

16.verse: They came to Balaam with this message: “King Balak pleads with you to come. He promises you great honors plus any payment you ask. Name your own figure! Only come and curse these people for us.”

17.verse: They came to Balaam with this message: “King Balak pleads with you to come. He promises you great honors plus any payment you ask. Name your own figure! Only come and curse these people for us.”

18.verse: But Balaam replied, “If he were to give me a palace filled with silver and gold, I could do nothing contrary to the command of the Lord my God.

19.verse: However, stay here tonight so that I can find out whether the Lord will add anything to what he said before.”

20.verse: That night God told Balaam, “You may get up and go with these men, but be sure to say only what I tell you to.”

21.verse: So the next morning he saddled his donkey and started off with them.

22.verse: But God was angry about Balaam’s eager attitude, so he sent an Angel to stand in the road to kill him. As Balaam and two servants were riding along, Balaam’s donkey suddenly saw the Angel of the Lord standing in the road with a drawn sword. She bolted off the road into a field, but Balaam beat her back onto the road.

23.verse: But God was angry about Balaam’s eager attitude, so he sent an Angel to stand in the road to kill him. As Balaam and two servants were riding along, Balaam’s donkey suddenly saw the Angel of the Lord standing in the road with a drawn sword. She bolted off the road into a field, but Balaam beat her back onto the road.

24.verse: Now the Angel of the Lord stood at a place where the road went between two vineyard walls.

25.verse: When the donkey saw him standing there, she squirmed past by pressing against the wall, crushing Balaam’s foot in the process. So he beat her again.

26.verse: Then the Angel of the Lord moved farther down the road and stood in a place so narrow that the donkey couldn’t get by at all.

27.verse: So she lay down in the road! In a great fit of temper Balaam beat her again with his staff.

28.verse: Then the Lord caused the donkey to speak! “What have I done that deserves your beating me these three times?” she asked.

29.verse: “Because you have made me look like a fool!” Balaam shouted. “I wish I had a sword with me, for I would kill you.”

30.verse: “Have I ever done anything like this before in my entire life?” the donkey asked. “No,” he admitted.

31.verse: Then the Lord opened Balaam’s eyes and he saw the Angel standing in the roadway with drawn sword, and he fell flat on the ground before him.

32.verse: “Why did you beat your donkey those three times?” the Angel demanded. “I have come to stop you because you are headed for destruction.

33.verse: Three times the donkey saw me and shied away from me; otherwise I would certainly have killed you by now and spared her.”

34.verse: Then Balaam confessed, “I have sinned. I didn’t realize you were there. I will go back home if you don’t want me to go on.”

35.verse: But the Angel told him, “Go with the men, but say only what I tell you to say.” So Balaam went on with them.

36.verse: When King Balak heard that Balaam was on the way, he left the capital and went out to meet him at the Arnon River, at the border of his land.

37.verse: “Why did you delay so long?” he asked Balaam. “Didn’t you believe me when I said I would give you great honors?”

38.verse: Balaam replied, “I have come, but I have no power to say anything except what God tells me to say; and that is what I shall speak.”

39.verse: Balaam accompanied the king to Kiriathhuzoth,

40.verse: where King Balak sacrificed oxen and sheep, and gave animals to Balaam and the ambassadors for their sacrifices.

41.verse: The next morning Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Bamoth-baal, from which he could see the people of Israel spread out before him.

1.verse: Balaam said to the king, “Build seven altars here, and prepare seven young bulls and seven rams for sacrifice.”

2.verse: Balak followed his instructions, and a young bull and a ram were sacrificed on each altar.

3.verse: Then Balaam said to the king, “Stand here by your burnt offerings and I will see if the Lord will meet me; and I will tell you what he says to me.” So he went up to a barren height, and God met him there. Balaam told the Lord, “I have prepared seven altars and have sacrificed a young bull and a ram on each.”

4.verse: Then Balaam said to the king, “Stand here by your burnt offerings and I will see if the Lord will meet me; and I will tell you what he says to me.” So he went up to a barren height, and God met him there. Balaam told the Lord, “I have prepared seven altars and have sacrificed a young bull and a ram on each.”

5.verse: Then the Lord gave Balaam a message for King Balak.

6.verse: When Balaam returned, the king was standing beside the burnt offerings with all the princes of Moab.

7.verse: This was Balaam’s message: “King Balak, king of Moab, has brought me From the land of Aram, From the eastern mountains. ‘Come,’ he told me, ‘curse Jacob for me! Let your anger rise on Israel.’ But how can I curse What God has not cursed? How can I denounce A people God has not denounced? I see them from the cliff tops, I watch them from the hills. They live alone, And prefer to remain distinct From every other nation. They are as numerous as dust! They are beyond numbering. If only I could die as happy as an Israelite! Oh, that my end might be like theirs!”

8.verse: This was Balaam’s message: “King Balak, king of Moab, has brought me From the land of Aram, From the eastern mountains. ‘Come,’ he told me, ‘curse Jacob for me! Let your anger rise on Israel.’ But how can I curse What God has not cursed? How can I denounce A people God has not denounced? I see them from the cliff tops, I watch them from the hills. They live alone, And prefer to remain distinct From every other nation. They are as numerous as dust! They are beyond numbering. If only I could die as happy as an Israelite! Oh, that my end might be like theirs!”

They live alone, And prefer to remain distinct From every other nation. They are as numerous as dust! They are beyond numbering. If only I could die as happy as an Israelite! Oh, that my end might be like theirs!”

10.verse: This was Balaam’s message: “King Balak, king of Moab, has brought me From the land of Aram, From the eastern mountains. ‘Come,’ he told me, ‘curse Jacob for me! Let your anger rise on Israel.’ But how can I curse What God has not cursed? How can I denounce A people God has not denounced? I see them from the cliff tops, I watch them from the hills. They live alone, And prefer to remain distinct From every other nation. They are as numerous as dust! They are beyond numbering. If only I could die as happy as an Israelite! Oh, that my end might be like theirs!”

11.verse: “What have you done to me?” demanded King Balak. “I told you to curse my enemies, and now you have blessed them!”

12.verse: But Balaam replied, “Can I say anything except what Jehovah tells me to?”

13.verse: Then Balak told him, “Come with me to another place; there you will see only a portion of the nation of Israel. Curse at least that many!”

14.verse: So King Balak took Balaam into the fields of Zophim at the top of Mount Pisgah, and built seven altars there; and he offered up a young bull and a ram on each altar.

15.verse: Then Balaam said to the king, “Stand here by your burnt offering while I go to meet the Lord.”

16.verse: And the Lord met Balaam and told him what to say.

17.verse: So he returned to where the king and the princes of Moab were standing beside their burnt offerings. “What has Jehovah said?” the king eagerly inquired.

18.verse: And he replied, “Rise up, Balak, and hear: Listen to me, you son of Zippor. God is not a man, that he should lie; He doesn’t change his mind like humans do. Has he ever promised, Without doing what he said? Look! I have received a command to bless them, For God has blessed them, And I cannot reverse it! He has not seen sin in Jacob. He will not trouble Israel! Jehovah their God is with them. He is their king! God has brought them out of Egypt. Israel has the strength of a wild ox. No curse can be placed on Jacob, And no magic shall be done against him. For now it shall be said of Israel, ‘What wonders God has done for them!’ These people rise up as a lion; They shall not lie down Until they have eaten what they capture And have drunk the blood of the slain!”

19.verse: And he replied, “Rise up, Balak, and hear: Listen to me, you son of Zippor. God is not a man, that he should lie; He doesn’t change his mind like humans do. 25.verse: “If you aren’t going to curse them, at least don’t bless them!” the king exclaimed to Balaam.

26.verse: But Balaam replied, “Didn’t I tell you that I must say whatever Jehovah tells me to?”

27.verse: Then the king said to Balaam, “I will take you to yet another place. Perhaps it will please God to let you curse them from there.”

28.verse: So King Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Peor, overlooking the desert.

29.verse: Balaam again told the king to build seven altars, and to prepare seven young bulls and seven rams for the sacrifice.

30.verse: The king did as Balaam said, and offered a young bull and ram on every altar.

1.verse: Balaam realized by now that Jehovah planned to bless Israel, so he didn’t even go to meet the Lord as he had earlier. Instead, he went at once and looked out toward the camp of Israel

2.verse: which stretched away across the plains, divided by tribal areas. Then the Spirit of God came upon him,

3.verse: and he spoke this prophecy concerning them: “Balaam the son of Beor says— The man whose eyes are open says— ‘I have listened to the word of God, I have seen what God Almighty showed me; I fell, and my eyes were opened: Oh, the joys awaiting Israel, Joys in the homes of Jacob. I see them spread before me as green valleys, And fruitful gardens by the riverside; As aloes planted by the Lord himself; As cedar trees beside the waters. They shall be blessed with an abundance of water, And they shall live in many places. Their king will be greater than Agag; Their kingdom is exalted. God has brought them from Egypt. Israel has the strength of a wild ox, And shall eat up the nations that oppose him; He shall break their bones in pieces, And shall shoot them with many arrows. Israel sleeps as a lion or a lioness— Who dares arouse him? Blessed is everyone who blesses you, O Israel, And curses shall fall upon everyone who curses you.’”

4.verse: and he spoke this prophecy concerning them: “Balaam the son of Beor says— The man whose eyes are open says— ‘I have listened to the word of God, I have seen what God Almighty showed me; I fell, and my eyes were opened: Oh, the joys awaiting Israel, Joys in the homes of Jacob. I see them spread before me as green valleys, And fruitful gardens by the riverside; As aloes planted by the Lord himself; As cedar trees beside the waters. Israel sleeps as a lion or a lioness— Who dares arouse him? Blessed is everyone who blesses you, O Israel, And curses shall fall upon everyone who curses you.’”

Israel has the strength of a wild ox, And shall eat up the nations that oppose him; He shall break their bones in pieces, And shall shoot them with many arrows. Israel sleeps as a lion or a lioness— Who dares arouse him? Blessed is everyone who blesses you, O Israel, And curses shall fall upon everyone who curses you.’”

8.verse: and he spoke this prophecy concerning them: “Balaam the son of Beor says— The man whose eyes are open says— ‘I have listened to the word of God, I have seen what God Almighty showed me; I fell, and my eyes were opened: Oh, the joys awaiting Israel, Joys in the homes of Jacob. I see them spread before me as green valleys, And fruitful gardens by the riverside; As aloes planted by the Lord himself; As cedar trees beside the waters. They shall be blessed with an abundance of water, And they shall live in many places. Their king will be greater than Agag; Their kingdom is exalted. God has brought them from Egypt. Israel has the strength of a wild ox, And shall eat up the nations that oppose him; He shall break their bones in pieces, And shall shoot them with many arrows. Israel sleeps as a lion or a lioness— Who dares arouse him? Blessed is everyone who blesses you, O Israel, And curses shall fall upon everyone who curses you.’”

9.verse: and he spoke this prophecy concerning them: “Balaam the son of Beor says— The man whose eyes are open says— ‘I have listened to the word of God, I have seen what God Almighty showed me; I fell, and my eyes were opened: Oh, the joys awaiting Israel, Joys in the homes of Jacob. I see them spread before me as green valleys, And fruitful gardens by the riverside; As aloes planted by the Lord himself; As cedar trees beside the waters. They shall be blessed with an abundance of water, And they shall live in many places. Their king will be greater than Agag; Their kingdom is exalted. God has brought them from Egypt. Israel has the strength of a wild ox, And shall eat up the nations that oppose him; He shall break their bones in pieces, And shall shoot them with many arrows. Israel sleeps as a lion or a lioness— Who dares arouse him? Blessed is everyone who blesses you, O Israel, And curses shall fall upon everyone who curses you.’”

10.verse: King Balak was livid with rage by now. Striking his hands together in anger and disgust he shouted, “I called you to curse my enemies and instead you have blessed them three times.

11.verse: Get out of here! Go back home! I had planned to promote you to great honor, but Jehovah has kept you from it!”

12.verse: Balaam replied, “Didn’t I tell your messengers

13.verse: that even if you gave me a palace filled with silver and gold, I could not go beyond the words of Jehovah, and could not say a word of my own? I said that I would say only what Jehovah says!

14.verse: Yes, I shall return now to my own people. But first, let me tell you what the Israelites are going to do to your people!”

15.verse: So he spoke this prophecy to him: “Balaam the son of Beor is the man Whose eyes are open! He hears the words of God And has knowledge from the Most High; He sees what Almighty God has shown him; He fell, and his eyes were opened: I see in the future of Israel, Far down the distant trail, That there shall come a star from Jacob! This ruler of Israel Shall smite the people of Moab, And destroy the sons of Sheth. Israel shall possess all Edom and Seir. They shall overcome their enemies. Jacob shall arise in power And shall destroy many cities.”

20.verse: Then Balaam looked over at the homes of the people of Amalek and prophesied: “Amalek was the first of the nations, But its destiny is destruction!”

21.verse: Then he looked over at the Kenites: “Yes, you are strongly situated, Your nest is set in the rocks! But the Kenites shall be destroyed, And the mighty army of the king of Assyria shall deport you from this land!”

22.verse: Then he looked over at the Kenites: “Yes, you are strongly situated, Your nest is set in the rocks! But the Kenites shall be destroyed, And the mighty army of the king of Assyria shall deport you from this land!”

23.verse: He concluded his prophecies by saying: “Alas, who can live when God does this? Ships shall come from the coasts of Cyprus, And shall oppress both Eber and Assyria. They too must be destroyed.”

24.verse: He concluded his prophecies by saying: “Alas, who can live when God does this? Ships shall come from the coasts of Cyprus, And shall oppress both Eber and Assyria. They too must be destroyed.”

25.verse: So Balaam and Balak returned to their homes.

1.verse: While Israel was camped at Acacia, some of the young men began going to wild parties with the local Moabite girls.

2.verse: These girls also invited them to attend the sacrifices to their gods, and soon the men were not only attending the feasts, but also bowing down and worshiping the idols.

3.verse: Before long all Israel was joining freely in the worship of Baal, the god of Moab; and the anger of the Lord was hot against his people.

4.verse: He issued the following command to Moses: “Execute all the tribal leaders of Israel. Hang them up before the Lord in broad daylight, so that his fierce anger will turn away from the people.”

5.verse: So Moses ordered the judges to execute all who had worshiped Baal.

6.verse: But one of the Israeli men insolently brought a Midianite girl into the camp, right before the eyes of Moses and all the people, as they were weeping at the door of the Tabernacle.

7.verse: When Phinehas (son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron the priest) saw this, he jumped up, grabbed a spear,

8.verse: and rushed after the man into his tent, where he had taken the girl. He thrust the spear all the way through the man’s body and into her stomach. So the plague was stopped,

9.verse: but only after 24,000 people had already died.

10.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Phinehas (son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron the priest) has turned away my anger for he was angry with my anger, and would not tolerate the worship of any God but me. So I have stopped destroying all Israel as I had intended.

11.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Phinehas (son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron the priest) has turned away my anger for he was angry with my anger, and would not tolerate the worship of any God but me. So I have stopped destroying all Israel as I had intended.

12.verse: Now because of what he has done—because of his zeal for his God, and because he has made atonement for the people of Israel by what he did—I promise that he and his descendants shall be priests forever.”

13.verse: Now because of what he has done—because of his zeal for his God, and because he has made atonement for the people of Israel by what he did—I promise that he and his descendants shall be priests forever.”

14.verse: The name of the man who was killed with the Midianite girl was Zimri, son of Salu, a leader of the tribe of Simeon.

15.verse: The girl’s name was Cozbi, daughter of Zur, a Midianite prince.

16.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Destroy the Midianites,

17.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Destroy the Midianites,

18.verse: for they are destroying you with their wiles. They are causing you to worship Baal, and they are leading you astray, as you have just seen by the death of Cozbi.”

1.verse: After the plague had ended, Jehovah said to Moses and to Eleazar (son of Aaron the priest),

2.verse: “Take a census of all the men of Israel who are twenty years old or older, to find out how many of each tribe and clan are able to go to war.”

3.verse: So Moses and Eleazar issued census instructions to the leaders of Israel. (The entire nation was camped in the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River, opposite Jericho.) Here are the results of the census:

4.verse: So Moses and Eleazar issued census instructions to the leaders of Israel. (The entire nation was camped in the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River, opposite Jericho.) Here are the results of the census:

5.verse: The tribe of Reuben: 43,730. (Reuben was Israel’s oldest son.) In this tribe were the following clans, named after Reuben’s sons: The Hanochites, named after their ancestor Hanoch. The Palluites, named after their ancestor Pallu. (In the subclan of Eliab—who was one of the sons of Pallu—were the families of Nemuel, Abiram, and Dathan. This Dathan and Abiram were the two leaders who conspired with Korah against Moses and Aaron, and in fact challenged the very authority of God! But the earth opened and swallowed them; and 250 men were destroyed by fire from the Lord that day, as a warning to the entire nation.) The Hezronites, named after their ancestor Hezron. The Carmites, named after their ancestor Carmi.

28.verse: The tribe of Joseph: 32,500 in the half-tribe of Ephraim; and 52,700 in the half-tribe of Manasseh. In the half-tribe of Manasseh was the clan of Machirites, named after their ancestor Machir. The subclan of the Machirites was the Gileadites, named after their ancestor Gilead. The tribes of the Gileadites: The Jezerites, named after their ancestor Jezer. The Helekites, named after their ancestor Helek. The Asrielites, named after their ancestor Asriel. The Shechemites, named after their ancestor Shechem. The Shemidaites, named after their ancestor Shemida. The Hepherites, named after their ancestor Hepher. (Hepher’s son, Zelophehad, had no sons. Here are the names of his daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, Tirzah.) The 32,500 registered in the half-tribe of Ephraim included the following clans, named after the sons of Ephraim: The Shuthelahites, named after their ancestor Shuthelah. (A subclan of the Shuthelahites was the Eranites, named after their ancestor Eran, a son of Shuthelah.) The Becherites, named after their ancestor Becher. The Tahanites, named after their ancestor Tahan.

The Shechemites, named after their ancestor Shechem. The Shemidaites, named after their ancestor Shemida. The Hepherites, named after their ancestor Hepher. (Hepher’s son, Zelophehad, had no sons. Here are the names of his daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, Tirzah.) The 32,500 registered in the half-tribe of Ephraim included the following clans, named after the sons of Ephraim: The Shuthelahites, named after their ancestor Shuthelah. (A subclan of the Shuthelahites was the Eranites, named after their ancestor Eran, a son of Shuthelah.) The Becherites, named after their ancestor Becher. The Tahanites, named after their ancestor Tahan.
