51.verse: So the total number of the men of draft age throughout Israel was 601,730.

52.verse: Then the Lord told Moses to divide the land among the tribes in proportion to their population, as indicated by the census—

53.verse: Then the Lord told Moses to divide the land among the tribes in proportion to their population, as indicated by the census—

54.verse: the larger tribes to be given more land, the smaller tribes less land.

55.verse: “Let the representatives of the larger tribes have a lottery, drawing for the larger sections,” the Lord instructed, “and let the smaller tribes draw for the smaller sections.”

56.verse: “Let the representatives of the larger tribes have a lottery, drawing for the larger sections,” the Lord instructed, “and let the smaller tribes draw for the smaller sections.”

57.verse: These are the clans of the Levites numbered in the census: The Gershonites, named after their ancestor Gershon. The Kohathites, named after their ancestor Kohath. The Merarites, named after their ancestor Merari.

58.verse: These are the families of the tribe of Levi: the Libnites, the Hebronites, the Mahlites, the Mushites, the Korahites. While Levi was in Egypt, a daughter, Jochebed, was born to him and she became the wife of Amram, son of Kohath. They were the parents of Aaron, Moses, and Miriam.

59.verse: These are the families of the tribe of Levi: the Libnites, the Hebronites, the Mahlites, the Mushites, the Korahites. While Levi was in Egypt, a daughter, Jochebed, was born to him and she became the wife of Amram, son of Kohath. They were the parents of Aaron, Moses, and Miriam.

60.verse: To Aaron were born Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

61.verse: But Nadab and Abihu died when they offered unauthorized incense before the Lord.

62.verse: The total number of Levites in the census was 23,000, counting all the males a month old and upward. But the Levites were not included in the total census figure of the people of Israel, for the Levites were given no land when it was divided among the tribes.

63.verse: So these are the census figures as prepared by Moses and Eleazar the priest, in the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River, across from Jericho.

64.verse: Not one person in this entire census had been counted in the previous census taken in the wilderness of Sinai! For all who had been counted then had died, as the Lord had decreed when he said of them, “They shall die in the wilderness.” The only exceptions were Caleb (son of Jephunneh) and Joshua (son of Nun).

65.verse: Not one person in this entire census had been counted in the previous census taken in the wilderness of Sinai! For all who had been counted then had died, as the Lord had decreed when he said of them, “They shall die in the wilderness.” The only exceptions were Caleb (son of Jephunneh) and Joshua (son of Nun).

1.verse: One day the daughters of Zelophehad came to the entrance of the Tabernacle to give a petition to Moses, Eleazar the priest, the tribal leaders, and others who were there. The names of these women were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. They were members of the half-tribe of Manasseh (a son of Joseph). Their ancestor was Machir, son of Manasseh. Manasseh’s son Gilead was their great-grandfather, his son Hepher was their grandfather, and his son Zelophehad was their father.

2.verse: One day the daughters of Zelophehad came to the entrance of the Tabernacle to give a petition to Moses, Eleazar the priest, the tribal leaders, and others who were there. The names of these women were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. They were members of the half-tribe of Manasseh (a son of Joseph). Their ancestor was Machir, son of Manasseh. Manasseh’s son Gilead was their great-grandfather, his son Hepher was their grandfather, and his son Zelophehad was their father.

3.verse: “Our father died in the wilderness,” they said, “and he was not one of those who perished in Korah’s revolt against the Lord—it was a natural death, but he had no sons. Why should the name of our father disappear just because he had no son? We feel that we should be given property along with our father’s brothers.”

4.verse: “Our father died in the wilderness,” they said, “and he was not one of those who perished in Korah’s revolt against the Lord—it was a natural death, but he had no sons. Why should the name of our father disappear just because he had no son? We feel that we should be given property along with our father’s brothers.”

5.verse: So Moses brought their case before the Lord.

6.verse: And the Lord replied to Moses, “The daughters of Zelophehad are correct. Give them land along with their uncles; give them the property that would have been given to their father if he had lived.

7.verse: And the Lord replied to Moses, “The daughters of Zelophehad are correct. Give them land along with their uncles; give them the property that would have been given to their father if he had lived.

8.verse: Moreover, this is a general law among you, that if a man dies and has no sons, then his inheritance shall be passed on to his daughters.

9.verse: And if he has no daughter, it shall belong to his brothers.

10.verse: And if he has no brother, then it shall go to his uncles.

11.verse: But if he has no uncles, then it shall go to the nearest relative.”

12.verse: One day the Lord said to Moses, “Go up into Mount Abarim and look across the river to the land I have given to the people of Israel.

13.verse: After you have seen it, you shall die as Aaron your brother did,

14.verse: for you rebelled against my instructions in the wilderness of Zin. When the people of Israel rebelled, you did not glorify me before them by following my instructions to order water to come out of the rock.” He was referring to the incident at the waters of Meribah (“Place of Strife”) in Kadesh, in the wilderness of Zin.

15.verse: Then Moses said to the Lord,

16.verse: “O Jehovah, the God of the spirits of all mankind, before I am taken away please appoint a new leader for the people,

17.verse: a man who will lead them into battle and care for them, so that the people of the Lord will not be as sheep without a shepherd.”

18.verse: The Lord replied, “Go and get Joshua (son of Nun), who has the Spirit in him,

19.verse: and take him to Eleazar the priest, and as all the people watch, charge him with the responsibility of leading the people.

20.verse: Publicly give him your authority so that all the people of Israel will obey him.

21.verse: He shall be the one to consult with Eleazar the priest in order to get directions from the Lord. The Lord will speak to Eleazar through the use of the Urim, and Eleazar will pass on these instructions to Joshua and the people. In this way the Lord will continue to give them guidance.”

22.verse: So Moses did as Jehovah commanded and took Joshua to Eleazar the priest. As the people watched,

23.verse: Moses laid his hands upon him and dedicated him to his responsibilities, as the Lord had commanded.

1.verse: The Lord gave Moses these instructions to give to the people of Israel: “The offerings which you burn on the altar for me are my food, and are a pleasure to me; so see to it that they are brought regularly and are offered as I have instructed you.

2.verse: The Lord gave Moses these instructions to give to the people of Israel: “The offerings which you burn on the altar for me are my food, and are a pleasure to me; so see to it that they are brought regularly and are offered as I have instructed you.

3.verse: “When you make offerings by fire, you shall use yearling male lambs—each without defect. Two of them shall be offered each day as a regular burnt offering.

4.verse: One lamb shall be sacrificed in the morning, the other in the evening.

5.verse: With them shall be offered a grain offering of three quarts of finely ground flour mixed with three pints of oil.

6.verse: This is the burnt offering ordained at Mount Sinai, to be regularly offered as a fragrant odor, an offering made by fire to the Lord.

7.verse: Along with it shall be the drink offering, consisting of three pints of strong wine with each lamb, poured out in the holy place before the Lord.

8.verse: Offer the second lamb in the evening with the same grain offering and drink offering. It too is a fragrant odor to the Lord, an offering made by fire.

9.verse: “On the Sabbath day, sacrifice two yearling male lambs—both without defect—in addition to the regular offerings. They are to be accompanied by a grain offering of six quarts of fine flour mixed with oil, and the usual drink offering.

10.verse: “On the Sabbath day, sacrifice two yearling male lambs—both without defect—in addition to the regular offerings. They are to be accompanied by a grain offering of six quarts of fine flour mixed with oil, and the usual drink offering.

11.verse: “Also, on the first day of each month there shall be an extra burnt offering to the Lord of two young bulls, one ram, and seven male yearling lambs—all without defect.

12.verse: Accompany them with nine quarts of finely ground flour mixed with oil as a grain offering with each bull; and six quarts of finely ground flour mixed with oil as a grain offering for the ram;

13.verse: and for each lamb, three quarts of finely ground flour mixed with oil for a grain offering. This burnt offering shall be presented by fire and will please the Lord very much.

14.verse: Along with each sacrifice shall be a drink offering—six pints of wine with each bull, four pints for a ram, and three pints for a lamb. This, then, will be the burnt offering each month throughout the year.

15.verse: “Also on the first day of each month you shall offer one male goat for a sin offering to the Lord. This is in addition to the regular daily burnt offering and its drink offering.

16.verse: “On April first you shall celebrate the Passover—when the death angel passed over the oldest sons of the Israelites in Egypt, leaving them unharmed.*

17.verse: On the following day a great, joyous seven-day festival will begin, but no leavened bread shall be served.

18.verse: On the first day of the festival all the people shall be called together before the Lord. No hard work shall be done on that day.

19.verse: You shall offer as burnt sacrifices to the Lord two young bulls, one ram, and seven yearling male lambs—all without defect.

20.verse: With each bull there shall be a grain offering of nine quarts of fine flour mixed with oil; with the ram there shall be six quarts; and with each of the seven lambs there shall be three quarts of fine flour.

21.verse: With each bull there shall be a grain offering of nine quarts of fine flour mixed with oil; with the ram there shall be six quarts; and with each of the seven lambs there shall be three quarts of fine flour.

22.verse: You must also offer a male goat as a sin offering, to make atonement for yourselves.

23.verse: These offerings shall be in addition to the usual daily sacrifices.

24.verse: This same sacrifice shall be offered on each of the seven days of the feast; they will be very pleasant to the Lord.

25.verse: On the seventh day there shall again be a holy and solemn assembly of all the people, and during that day you may do no hard work.

26.verse: “On the first day of the Harvest Festival all the people must come before the Lord for a special, solemn assembly to celebrate the new harvest. On that day you are to present the first of the new crop of grain as a grain offering to the Lord; there is to be no regular work by anyone on that day.

27.verse: A special burnt offering, very pleasant to the Lord, shall be offered that day. It shall consist of two young bulls, one ram, and seven yearling male lambs.

28.verse: These shall be accompanied by your grain offering of nine quarts of fine flour mixed with oil with each bull, six quarts with the ram, and three quarts with each of the seven lambs.

29.verse: These shall be accompanied by your grain offering of nine quarts of fine flour mixed with oil with each bull, six quarts with the ram, and three quarts with each of the seven lambs.

30.verse: Also offer one male goat to make atonement for yourselves.

31.verse: These special offerings are in addition to the regular daily burnt offerings and grain offerings and drink offerings. Make sure that the animals you sacrifice are without defect.

1.verse: “The Festival of Trumpets shall be celebrated on the fifteenth day of September each year; there shall be a solemn assembly of all the people on that day, and no hard work may be done.

2.verse: On that day you shall offer a burnt sacrifice consisting of one young bull, one ram, and seven yearling male lambs—all without defect. These are sacrifices which the Lord will appreciate and enjoy.

3.verse: A grain offering of nine quarts of fine flour mingled with oil shall be offered with the bull, six quarts with the ram, and three quarts with each of the seven lambs.

4.verse: A grain offering of nine quarts of fine flour mingled with oil shall be offered with the bull, six quarts with the ram, and three quarts with each of the seven lambs.

5.verse: In addition, there shall be a male goat sacrificed as a sin offering, to make atonement for you.

6.verse: These special sacrifices are in addition to the regular monthly burnt offering for that day, and also in addition to the regular daily burnt sacrifices, which are to be offered with the respective grain offerings and drink offerings, as specified by the ordinances governing them.

7.verse: “Ten days later another convocation of all the people shall be held. This will be a day of solemn humility before the Lord, and no work of any kind may be done.

8.verse: On that day you shall offer a burnt sacrifice to the Lord—it will be very pleasant to him—of one young bull, one ram, seven yearling male lambs—each without defect—

9.verse: and their accompanying grain offerings. Nine quarts of fine flour mixed with oil are to be offered with the bull, six with the ram, and three with each of the seven lambs.

10.verse: and their accompanying grain offerings. Nine quarts of fine flour mixed with oil are to be offered with the bull, six with the ram, and three with each of the seven lambs.

11.verse: You are also to sacrifice one male goat for a sin offering. This is in addition to the sin offering of the Day of Atonement offered annually on that day, and in addition to the regular daily burnt sacrifices, grain offerings, and drink offerings.

12.verse: “Five days later there shall be yet another assembly of all the people, and on that day no hard work shall be done; it is the beginning of a seven-day festival before the Lord.

13.verse: Your special burnt sacrifice that day, which will give much pleasure to the Lord, shall be thirteen young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—

14.verse: accompanied by the usual grain offerings—nine quarts of fine flour mingled with oil for each of the thirteen young bulls; six quarts for each of the two rams;

15.verse: and three quarts for each of the fourteen lambs.

16.verse: There must also be a male goat sacrificed for a sin offering, in addition to the regular daily burnt sacrifice with its accompanying grain offerings and drink offerings.

17.verse: “On the second day of this seven-day festival you shall sacrifice twelve young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—

18.verse: accompanied by the usual grain offerings and drink offerings.

19.verse: Also, in addition to the regular daily burnt sacrifice, you are to sacrifice a male goat with its accompanying grain offering and drink offering for a sin offering.

20.verse: “On the third day of the festival, offer eleven young bulls, two rams, fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—

21.verse: and the usual grain offering and drink offering with each sacrifice.

22.verse: And in addition to the regular daily burnt sacrifices, sacrifice a male goat for a sin offering, with its accompanying grain offering and drink offering.

23.verse: “On the fourth day of the festival, you are to sacrifice ten young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—

24.verse: each with its accompanying grain offering and drink offering;

25.verse: also a male goat as a sin offering (along with the usual grain and drink offerings) in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.

26.verse: “On the fifth day of the festival, sacrifice nine young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—accompanied by the usual grain offerings and drink offerings;

27.verse: “On the fifth day of the festival, sacrifice nine young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—accompanied by the usual grain offerings and drink offerings;

28.verse: also sacrifice a male goat with the usual grain and drink offerings, as a special sin offering, in addition to the usual daily sacrifices.

29.verse: “On the sixth day of the festival, you must sacrifice eight young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—

30.verse: along with their usual grain and drink offerings.

31.verse: In addition to the usual daily sacrifices, sacrifice a male goat and the usual grain and drink offerings as a sin offering.

32.verse: “On the seventh day of the festival, sacrifice seven young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male yearling lambs—each without defect—

33.verse: each with its customary grain and drink offerings;

34.verse: also sacrifice an extra sin offering of one male goat, with the usual grain and drink offerings, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.

35.verse: “On the eighth day summon the people to another solemn assembly; you must do no hard work that day.

36.verse: Sacrifice a burnt offering—they are very pleasant to the Lord—of one young bull, one ram, seven male yearling lambs—each without defect—

37.verse: and the customary grain and drink offerings.

38.verse: Sacrifice also one male goat with the usual grain and drink offerings for a sin offering, in addition to the regular daily sacrifices.

39.verse: These offerings are compulsory at the times of your annual feasts, and are in addition to sacrifices and offerings you present in connection with vows, or as freewill offerings, burnt sacrifices, grain offerings, drink offerings, or peace offerings.”

40.verse: So Moses gave all of these instructions to the people of Israel.

1.verse: Now Moses summoned the leaders of the tribes and told them, “The Lord has commanded that when anyone makes a promise to the Lord, either to do something or to quit doing something, that vow must not be broken: the person making the vow must do exactly as he has promised.

2.verse: Now Moses summoned the leaders of the tribes and told them, “The Lord has commanded that when anyone makes a promise to the Lord, either to do something or to quit doing something, that vow must not be broken: the person making the vow must do exactly as he has promised.

3.verse: “If a woman promises the Lord to do or not do something, and she is still a girl at home in her father’s home,

4.verse: and her father hears that she has made a vow with penalties, but says nothing, then her vow shall stand.

5.verse: But if her father refuses to let her make the vow, or feels that the penalties she has agreed to are too harsh, then her promise will automatically become invalid. Her father must state his disagreement on the first day he hears about it; and then Jehovah will forgive her because her father would not let her do it.

6.verse: “If she takes a vow or makes a foolish pledge, and later marries,

7.verse: and her husband learns of her vow and says nothing on the day he hears of it, her vow shall stand.

8.verse: But if her husband refuses to accept her vow or foolish pledge, his disagreement makes it void, and Jehovah will forgive her.

9.verse: “But if the woman is a widow or is divorced, she must fulfill her vow.

10.verse: “If she is married and living in her husband’s home when she makes the vow,

11.verse: and her husband hears of it and does nothing, the vow shall stand;

12.verse: but if he refuses to allow it on the first day he hears of it, her vow is void and Jehovah will forgive her.

13.verse: So her husband may either confirm or nullify her vow,

14.verse: but if he says nothing for a day, then he has already agreed to it.

15.verse: If he waits more than a day and then refuses to permit the vow, whatever penalties to which she agreed shall come upon him—he shall be responsible.”

16.verse: These, then, are the commandments the Lord gave Moses concerning relationships between a man and his wife and between a father and his daughter who is living at home.

1.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Take vengeance on the Midianites for leading you into idolatry, and then you must die.”

2.verse: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Take vengeance on the Midianites for leading you into idolatry, and then you must die.”

3.verse: Moses said to the people, “Some of you must take arms to wage Jehovah’s war against Midian.

4.verse: Conscript 1,000 men from each tribe.” So this was done; and out of the many thousands of Israel, 12,000 armed men were sent to battle by Moses.

5.verse: Conscript 1,000 men from each tribe.” So this was done; and out of the many thousands of Israel, 12,000 armed men were sent to battle by Moses.

6.verse: Phinehas (son of Eleazar the priest) led them into battle, accompanied by the Ark, with trumpets blaring.

7.verse: And every man of Midian was killed.

8.verse: Among those killed were all five of the Midianite kings—Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba. Balaam, the son of Beor, was also killed.

9.verse: Then the Israeli army took as captives all the women and children, and seized the cattle and flocks and a lot of miscellaneous booty. All of the cities, towns, and villages of Midian were then burned.

10.verse: Then the Israeli army took as captives all the women and children, and seized the cattle and flocks and a lot of miscellaneous booty. All of the cities, towns, and villages of Midian were then burned.

11.verse: Then the Israeli army took as captives all the women and children, and seized the cattle and flocks and a lot of miscellaneous booty. All of the cities, towns, and villages of Midian were then burned.

12.verse: The captives and other war loot were brought to Moses and Eleazar the priest, and to the rest of the people of Israel who were camped on the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River, across from Jericho.

13.verse: Moses and Eleazar the priest and all the leaders of the people went out to meet the victorious army,

14.verse: but Moses was very angry with the army officers and battalion leaders.

15.verse: “Why have you let all the women live?” he demanded.

16.verse: “These are the very ones who followed Balaam’s advice and caused the people of Israel to worship idols on Mount Peor, and they are the cause of the plague that destroyed us.

17.verse: Now kill all the boys and all the women who have had sexual intercourse.

18.verse: Only the little girls may live; you may keep them for yourselves.

19.verse: Now stay outside of the camp for seven days, all of you who have killed anyone or touched a dead body. Then purify yourselves and your captives on the third and seventh days.

20.verse: Remember also to purify all your garments and everything made of leather, goat’s hair, or wood.”

21.verse: Then Eleazar the priest said to the men who were in the battle, “This is the commandment Jehovah has given Moses:

22.verse: ‘Anything that will stand heat—such as gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, or lead—

23.verse: shall be passed through fire in order to be made ceremonially pure; it must then be further purified with the purification water. But anything that won’t stand heat shall be purified by the water alone.’

24.verse: On the seventh day you must wash your clothes and be purified, and then you may come back into the camp.”

25.verse: And the Lord said to Moses,

26.verse: “You and Eleazar the priest and the leaders of the tribes are to make a list of all the loot, including the people and animals;

27.verse: then divide it into two parts. Half of it is for the men who were in the battle, and the other half is to be given to the people of Israel.

28.verse: But first, the Lord gets a share of all the captives, oxen, donkeys, and flocks kept by the army. His share is one out of every five hundred.

29.verse: Give this share to Eleazar the priest to be presented to the Lord by the gesture of waving before the altar.

30.verse: Also levy a 2 percent tribute of all the captives, flocks, and cattle that are given to the people of Israel. Present this to the Levites in charge of the Tabernacle, for it is the Lord’s portion.”

31.verse: So Moses and Eleazar the priest did as the Lord commanded.

32.verse: The total booty (besides the jewelry, clothing, etc., which the soldiers kept for themselves) was 675,000 sheep; 72,000 oxen; 61,000 donkeys; and 32,000 young girls.

33.verse: The total booty (besides the jewelry, clothing, etc., which the soldiers kept for themselves) was 675,000 sheep; 72,000 oxen; 61,000 donkeys; and 32,000 young girls.

36.verse: So the half given to the army totaled: 337,500 sheep (of which 675 were given to the Lord); 36,000 oxen (of which 72 were given to the Lord); 30,500 donkeys (of which 61 were given to the Lord); 16,000 girls (of whom 32 went to the Levites).

41.verse: All of the Lord’s portion was given to Eleazar the priest, as the Lord had directed Moses.

42.verse: The half of the booty assigned to the people of Israel—Moses had separated it from the half belonging to the warriors—amounted to: 337,500 sheep, 36,000 oxen, 30,500 donkeys, and 16,000 girls.

47.verse: In accordance with the Lord’s directions, Moses gave 2 percent of these to the Levites.

48.verse: Then the officers and battalion leaders came to Moses and said, “We have accounted for all the men who went out to battle, and not one of us is missing!

49.verse: Then the officers and battalion leaders came to Moses and said, “We have accounted for all the men who went out to battle, and not one of us is missing!

50.verse: So we have brought a special thank offering to the Lord from our loot—gold jewelry, bracelets, anklets, rings, earrings, and necklaces. This is to make atonement for our souls before the Lord.”

51.verse: Moses and Eleazar the priest received this special offering from the captains and battalion leaders and company commanders, and found its total value to be more than $300,000.

52.verse: Moses and Eleazar the priest received this special offering from the captains and battalion leaders and company commanders, and found its total value to be more than $300,000.

53.verse: (The soldiers had also kept personal loot for themselves.)

54.verse: The offering was taken into the Tabernacle and kept there before the Lord as a memorial of the people of Israel.

1.verse: When Israel arrived in the land of Jazar and Gilead, the tribes of Reuben and Gad (who had large flocks of sheep) noticed what wonderful sheep country it was.

2.verse: So they came to Moses and Eleazar the priest and the other tribal leaders and said,

3.verse: “The Lord has used Israel to destroy the population of this whole countryside—Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo, and Beon. And it is all wonderful sheep country, ideal for our flocks.

4.verse: “The Lord has used Israel to destroy the population of this whole countryside—Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo, and Beon. And it is all wonderful sheep country, ideal for our flocks.

5.verse: Please let us have this land as our portion instead of the land on the other side of the Jordan River.”

6.verse: “You mean you want to sit here while your brothers go across and do all the fighting?” Moses demanded.

7.verse: “Are you trying to discourage the rest of the people from going across to the land that the Lord has given them?

8.verse: This is the same kind of thing your fathers did! I sent them from Kadesh-barnea to spy out the land,

9.verse: but when they finished their survey and returned from the valley of Eshcol, they discouraged the people from going on into the Promised Land.

10.verse: And the Lord’s anger was hot against them, and he swore that of all those he had rescued from Egypt, no one over twenty years of age would ever see the land he promised Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, for they had refused to do what he wanted them to.

11.verse: And the Lord’s anger was hot against them, and he swore that of all those he had rescued from Egypt, no one over twenty years of age would ever see the land he promised Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, for they had refused to do what he wanted them to.

12.verse: “The only exceptions were Caleb (son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite) and Joshua (son of Nun)—for they wholeheartedly followed the Lord and urged the people to go on into the Promised Land.

13.verse: “The Lord made us wander back and forth in the wilderness for forty years until all that evil generation died.

14.verse: But here you are, a brood of sinners doing exactly the same thing! Only there are more of you, so Jehovah’s anger against Israel will be even fiercer this time.

15.verse: If you turn away from God like this, he will make the people stay even longer in the wilderness, and you will be responsible for destroying his people and bringing disaster to this entire nation!”

16.verse: “Not at all!” they explained. “We will build sheepfolds for our flocks and cities for our little ones,

17.verse: but we ourselves will go over armed, ahead of the rest of the people of Israel, until we have brought them safely to their inheritance. But first we will need to build walled cities here for our families, to keep them safe from attack by the local inhabitants.

18.verse: We will not settle down here until all the people of Israel have received their inheritance.

19.verse: We don’t want land on the other side of the Jordan; we would rather have it on this side, on the east.”

20.verse: Then Moses said, “All right, if you will do what you have said and arm yourselves for Jehovah’s war,

21.verse: and keep your troops across the Jordan until the Lord has driven out his enemies,

22.verse: then, when the land is finally subdued before the Lord, you may return. Then you will have discharged your duty to the Lord and to the rest of the people of Israel. And the land on the eastern side shall be your possession from the Lord.

23.verse: But if you don’t do as you have said, then you will have sinned against the Lord, and you may be sure that your sin will catch up with you.

24.verse: Go ahead and build cities for your families and sheepfolds for your sheep, and do all you have said.”

25.verse: “We will follow your instructions exactly,” the people of Gad and Reuben replied.

26.verse: “Our children, wives, flocks, and cattle shall stay here in the cities of Gilead.

27.verse: But all of us who are conscripted will go over to battle for the Lord, just as you have said.”

28.verse: So Moses gave his approval by saying to Eleazar, Joshua, and the tribal leaders of Israel,

29.verse: “If all the men of the tribes of Gad and Reuben who are conscripted for the Lord’s battles go with you over the Jordan, then, when the land is conquered, you must give them the land of Gilead;

30.verse: but if they refuse, then they must accept land among the rest of you in the land of Canaan.”

31.verse: The tribes of Gad and Reuben said again, “As the Lord has commanded, so we will do—

32.verse: we will follow the Lord fully armed into Canaan, but our own land shall be here on this side of the Jordan.”

33.verse: So Moses assigned the territory of King Sihon of the Amorites, and of King Og of Bashan—all the land and cities—to the tribes of Gad, Reuben, and the half-tribe of Manasseh (son of Joseph).

34.verse: The people of Gad built these cities: Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer, Atroth-shophan, Jazer, Jogbehah, Beth-nimrah, Beth-haran. They were all fortified cities with sheepfolds.

35.verse: The people of Gad built these cities: Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer, Atroth-shophan, Jazer, Jogbehah, Beth-nimrah, Beth-haran. They were all fortified cities with sheepfolds.

36.verse: The people of Gad built these cities: Dibon, Ataroth, Aroer, Atroth-shophan, Jazer, Jogbehah, Beth-nimrah, Beth-haran. They were all fortified cities with sheepfolds.

37.verse: The children of Reuben built the following cities: Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim, Nebo, Baal-meon, Sibmah. (The Israelites later changed the names of some of these cities they had conquered and rebuilt.)

38.verse: The children of Reuben built the following cities: Heshbon, Elealeh, Kiriathaim, Nebo, Baal-meon, Sibmah. (The Israelites later changed the names of some of these cities they had conquered and rebuilt.)

39.verse: Then the clan of Machir of the tribe of Manasseh went to Gilead and conquered it, and drove out the Amorites who were living there.

40.verse: So Moses gave Gilead to the Machirites, and they lived there.

41.verse: The men of Jair, another clan of the tribe of Manasseh, occupied many of the towns in Gilead, and changed the name of their area to Havroth-jair.

42.verse: Meanwhile, a man named Nobah led an army to Kenath and its surrounding villages, and occupied them, and he called the area Nobah, after his own name.

1.verse: This is the itinerary of the nation of Israel from the time Moses and Aaron led them out of Egypt.

2.verse: Moses had written down their movements as the Lord had instructed him.

3.verse: They left the city of Rameses, Egypt, on the first day of April, the day after the night of the Passover. They left proudly, hurried along by the Egyptians who were burying all their eldest sons, killed by the Lord the night before. The Lord had certainly defeated all the gods of Egypt that night!

4.verse: They left the city of Rameses, Egypt, on the first day of April, the day after the night of the Passover. They left proudly, hurried along by the Egyptians who were burying all their eldest sons, killed by the Lord the night before. The Lord had certainly defeated all the gods of Egypt that night!

5.verse: After leaving Rameses, they stayed in Succoth, Etham (at the edge of the wilderness), and

6.verse: After leaving Rameses, they stayed in Succoth, Etham (at the edge of the wilderness), and

7.verse: Pihahiroth (near Baal-zephon, where they camped at the foot of Mount Migdol).

8.verse: From there they went through the middle of the Red Sea and on for three days into the wilderness of Etham, camping at Marah.

9.verse: Leaving Marah, they came to Elim, where there are twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees; they stayed there for quite a long time.

10.verse: Leaving Elim, they camped beside the Red Sea,

11.verse: and then in the wilderness of Sihn.

12.verse: Next was Dophkah,

13.verse: and then Alush;

14.verse: then on to Rephidim (where there was no water for the people to drink).

38.verse: While they were at the foot of Mount Hor, Aaron the priest was directed by the Lord to go up into the mountain, and there he died. This occurred during the fortieth year after the people of Israel had left Egypt. The date of his death was July 15, when he was 123 years old.

39.verse: While they were at the foot of Mount Hor, Aaron the priest was directed by the Lord to go up into the mountain, and there he died. This occurred during the fortieth year after the people of Israel had left Egypt. The date of his death was July 15, when he was 123 years old.

40.verse: It was then that the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negeb, in the land of Canaan, heard that the people of Israel were approaching his land.

41.verse: After dealing with him, the Israelis journeyed from Mount Hor and camped in Zalmonah,

44.verse: then Iyeabarim (at the border of Moab).

45.verse: From there they went to Dibon-gad,

47.verse: and on into the mountains of Abarim, near Mount Nebo,

48.verse: and finally to the plains of Moab beside the river Jordan, opposite Jericho.

49.verse: While in that area they camped at various places along the Jordan River, from Bethjeshimoth as far as Abel-shittim, on the plains of Moab.

50.verse: It was while they were camped there that the Lord told Moses to tell the people of Israel, “When you pass across the Jordan River into the land of Canaan,

51.verse: It was while they were camped there that the Lord told Moses to tell the people of Israel, “When you pass across the Jordan River into the land of Canaan,

52.verse: you must drive out all the people living there and destroy all their idols—their carved stones, molten images, and the open-air sanctuaries in the hills where they worship their idols.

53.verse: I have given the land to you; take it and live there.

54.verse: You will be given land in proportion to the size of your tribes. The larger sections of land will be divided by lot among the larger tribes, and the smaller sections will be allotted to the smaller tribes.

55.verse: But if you refuse to drive out the people living there, those who remain will be as cinders in your eyes and thorns in your sides.

56.verse: And I will destroy you as I had planned for you to destroy them.”

1.verse: The Lord told Moses to tell the people of Israel, “When you come into the land of Canaan (I am giving you the entire land as your homeland),

2.verse: The Lord told Moses to tell the people of Israel, “When you come into the land of Canaan (I am giving you the entire land as your homeland),

3.verse: the southern portion of the country will be the wilderness of Zin, along the edge of Edom. The southern boundary will begin at the Dead Sea,

4.verse: and will continue south past Scorpion Pass in the direction of Zin. Its southernmost point will be Kadesh-barnea, from which it will go to Hazaraddar, and on to Azmon.

5.verse: From Azmon the boundary will follow the brook of Egypt down to the Mediterranean Sea.

6.verse: “Your western boundary will be the coastline of the Mediterranean Sea.

7.verse: “Your northern border will begin at the Mediterranean Sea and will proceed eastward to Mount Hor, then to Lebo-Hamath, and on through Zedad and Ziphron to Hazar-enan.

8.verse: “Your northern border will begin at the Mediterranean Sea and will proceed eastward to Mount Hor, then to Lebo-Hamath, and on through Zedad and Ziphron to Hazar-enan.

9.verse: “Your northern border will begin at the Mediterranean Sea and will proceed eastward to Mount Hor, then to Lebo-Hamath, and on through Zedad and Ziphron to Hazar-enan.

10.verse: “The eastern border will be from Hazar-enan south to Shepham, then on to Riblah at the east side of Ain. From there it will make a large half-circle, first going south and then westward until it touches the southernmost tip of the Sea of Galilee,

11.verse: “The eastern border will be from Hazar-enan south to Shepham, then on to Riblah at the east side of Ain. From there it will make a large half-circle, first going south and then westward until it touches the southernmost tip of the Sea of Galilee,

12.verse: and then along the Jordan River, ending at the Dead Sea.”

13.verse: “This is the territory you are to apportion among yourselves by lot,” Moses said. “It is to be divided up among the nine and one-half tribes,

14.verse: for the tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh have already been assigned land on the east side of the Jordan, opposite Jericho.”

15.verse: for the tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh have already been assigned land on the east side of the Jordan, opposite Jericho.”

1.verse: While Israel was camped beside the Jordan on the plains of Moab, opposite Jericho, the Lord said to Moses,

2.verse: “Instruct the people of Israel to give to the Levites as their inheritance certain cities and surrounding pasturelands.

3.verse: These cities are for their homes, and the surrounding lands for their cattle, flocks, and other livestock.

4.verse: Their gardens and vineyards shall extend 1500 feet out from the city walls in each direction, with an additional 1500 feet beyond that for pastureland.

5.verse: Their gardens and vineyards shall extend 1500 feet out from the city walls in each direction, with an additional 1500 feet beyond that for pastureland.

6.verse: “You shall give the Levites the six Cities of Refuge, where a person who has accidentally killed someone can run and be safe, and forty-two other cities besides.

7.verse: In all, there shall be forty-eight cities with the surrounding pastureland given to the Levites.

8.verse: These cities shall be in various parts of the nation; the larger tribes with many cities will give several to the Levites, while the smaller tribes will give fewer.”

9.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “Tell the people that when they arrive in the land,

10.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “Tell the people that when they arrive in the land,

11.verse: Cities of Refuge shall be designated for anyone to flee into if he has killed someone accidentally.

12.verse: These cities will be places of protection from the dead man’s relatives who want to avenge his death; for the slayer must not be killed unless a fair trial establishes his guilt.

13.verse: Three of these six Cities of Refuge are to be located in the land of Canaan, and three on the east side of the Jordan River.

14.verse: Three of these six Cities of Refuge are to be located in the land of Canaan, and three on the east side of the Jordan River.

15.verse: These are not only for the protection of Israelites, but also for foreigners and travelers.

16.verse: “But if someone is struck and killed by a piece of iron, it must be presumed to be murder, and the murderer must be executed.

17.verse: Or if the slain man was struck down with a large stone, it is murder, and the murderer shall die.

18.verse: The same is true if he is killed with a wooden weapon.

19.verse: The avenger of his death shall personally kill the murderer when he meets him.

20.verse: So if anyone kills another out of hatred by throwing something at him, or ambushing him,

21.verse: or angrily striking him with his fist so that he dies, he is a murderer; and the murderer shall be executed by the avenger.

22.verse: “But if it is an accident—a case in which something is thrown unintentionally, or in which a stone is thrown without anger, without realizing it will hit anyone, and without wanting to harm an enemy—yet the man dies,

23.verse: “But if it is an accident—a case in which something is thrown unintentionally, or in which a stone is thrown without anger, without realizing it will hit anyone, and without wanting to harm an enemy—yet the man dies,

24.verse: then the people shall judge whether or not it was an accident, and whether or not to hand the killer over to the avenger of the dead man.

25.verse: If it is decided that it was accidental, then the people shall save the killer from the avenger; the killer shall be permitted to stay in the City of Refuge; and he must live there until the death of the High Priest.

26.verse: “If the slayer leaves the city,

27.verse: and the avenger finds him outside and kills him, it is not murder,

28.verse: for the man should have stayed inside the city until the death of the High Priest. But after the death of the High Priest, the man may return to his own land and home.

29.verse: These are permanent laws for all Israel from generation to generation.

30.verse: “All murderers must be executed, but only if there is more than one witness; no man shall die with only one person testifying against him.

31.verse: Whenever anyone is judged guilty of murder, he must die—no ransom may be accepted for him.

32.verse: Nor may a payment be accepted from a refugee in a City of Refuge, permitting him to return to his home before the death of the High Priest.

33.verse: In this way the land will not be polluted, for murder pollutes the land, and no atonement can be made for murder except by the execution of the murderer.

34.verse: You shall not defile the land where you are going to live, for I, Jehovah, will be living there.”

1.verse: Then the heads of the subclan of Gilead (of the clan of Machir, of the tribe of Manasseh, one of the sons of Joseph) came to Moses and the leaders of Israel with a petition: “The Lord instructed you to divide the land by lot among the people of Israel,” they reminded Moses, “and to give the inheritance of our brother Zelophehad to his daughters.

2.verse: Then the heads of the subclan of Gilead (of the clan of Machir, of the tribe of Manasseh, one of the sons of Joseph) came to Moses and the leaders of Israel with a petition: “The Lord instructed you to divide the land by lot among the people of Israel,” they reminded Moses, “and to give the inheritance of our brother Zelophehad to his daughters.

3.verse: But if they marry into another tribe, their land will go with them to the tribe into which they marry. In this way the total area of our tribe will be reduced

4.verse: and will not be returned at the Year of Jubilee.”

5.verse: Then Moses replied publicly, giving them these instructions from the Lord: “The men of the tribe of Joseph have a proper complaint.

6.verse: This is what the Lord has further commanded concerning the daughters of Zelophehad: ‘Let them be married to anyone they like, so long as it is within their own tribe.

7.verse: In this way none of the land of the tribe will shift to any other tribe, for the inheritance of every tribe is to remain permanently as it was first allotted.

8.verse: The girls throughout the tribes of Israel who are heiresses must marry within their own tribe, so that their land won’t leave the tribe.

9.verse: In this way no inheritance shall move from one tribe to another.’”

10.verse: The daughters of Zelophehad did as the Lord commanded Moses.

11.verse: These girls, Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah, were married to men in their own tribe of Manasseh (son of Joseph); so their inheritance remained in their tribe.

12.verse: These girls, Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah, were married to men in their own tribe of Manasseh (son of Joseph); so their inheritance remained in their tribe.

13.verse: These are the commandments and ordinances that the Lord gave to the people of Israel through Moses, while they were camped on the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River, across from Jericho.
